intro: Neoxythece tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its dense, woolly foliage that gives it its common name. The plant typically grows on the branches of host trees, such as those in the genus Ficus, and derives some of its nutrients from the host. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are usually greenish-white in color, and it produces small, fleshy berries that are dispersed by birds. Due to its parasitic nature and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and specialized species.
